metadata.case_name: Gurubachan Singh v. Respondents (Commissioner of Police, Bombay)

facts.text: Petitioner Gurubachan Singh is an Indian citizen residing with his father at Gogri Niwas, Vincent Road, Dadar; father has business in electrical goods in Bombay.

On 23rd July 1951, petitioner served with externment order by Commissioner of Police, Bombay under section 27(1) of City of Bombay Police Act 1902, directing removal from Greater Bombay to Amritsar in East Punjab by rail within two days.
On July 25 1951, petitioner applied to Commissioner for extension of time, granted till 30th July 1951.
On 30th July 1951, petitioner wrote to Commissioner requesting to stay at Kalyan (outside Greater Bombay but within State of Bombay) instead of Amritsar, with railway ticket from Dadar.
Police took petitioner to Kalyan on evening of 30th July 1951 and left him there, with sanction of Commissioner.

Petitioner filed proceedings in Bombay High Court: first on original side under Letters Patent, then Appellate Criminal Bench under Articles 226 and 228, seeking certiorari to quash externment order; both dismissed.
Petitioner approached Supreme Court under Article 32 alleging infringement of fundamental rights under clauses (d) and (e) of Article 19(1).

legal_issues.text: Whether the externment order is void as not in conformity with section 27(1) of City of Bombay Police Act.
Whether section 27(1) of City of Bombay Police Act conflicts with fundamental rights under clauses (d) and (e) of Article 19(1) and is void under Article 13(1).
Whether section 27(1) is discriminatory and offends Article 14.

petitioner_arguments.text: Order of externment void as not in conformity with section 27(1); directed removal from Greater Bombay but specified Amritsar outside State, without specifying place within State.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 27(1) City of Bombay Police Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 27(1) imposes restrictions conflicting with Article 19(1)(d) and (e), void under Article 13(1).
Procedure under section 27(4) unreasonable as no right to cross-examine witnesses.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 27(4) City of Bombay Police Act; Article 19(5)

respondent_arguments.text: Original order not in strict conformity but irregularity cured by petitioner's subsequent conduct and Commissioner's approval; order construed as externment from Greater Bombay with Kalyan as place.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 27(1) City of Bombay Police Act

court_reasoning.text: Section 27(1) contemplates two kinds of orders: from Greater Bombay (must specify place within State and route) or from State (no place needed). Original order irregular as specified Amritsar outside State, but petitioner's request to go to Kalyan accepted and effected by police cures defect; order construed as from Greater Bombay to Kalyan.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Subsequent conduct of petitioner with sanction of Commissioner removed any defect.

court_reasoning.text: Section 27(1) imposes restrictions in interest of general public to protect against dangerous characters; maximum 2 years, can be revoked earlier; reasonable under Article 19(5).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Restrictions reasonable considering class of cases and menace averted.

court_reasoning.text: Procedure under section 27(4): informed of allegations, opportunity to explain, appear through advocate, file statement, examine witnesses; no cross-examination needed as witnesses fear violence; power with high officer acting cautiously.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Procedure reasonable for exceptional cases where public witnesses unavailable due to fear.

holdings.text: No substance in challenge to order's conformity with section 27(1); irregularity cured.
Restrictions under section 27(1) reasonable under Article 19(5); not void under Article 13(1).
Section 27(1) not addressed on Article 14 as urged faintly.

statutes_cited.name: City of Bombay Police Act, 1902
statutes_cited.relevance: Empowers externment orders; procedure and reasonableness upheld.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Article 32 invoked; Articles 19(1)(d)(e) rights not infringed unreasonably; not discriminatory.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences involving force/violence or specified chapters trigger externment.

outcome.summary: Petition under Article 32 dismissed; externment order upheld as valid and constitutional.

key_quotes.text: "the subsequent conduct of the petitioner which had the sanction and approval of the Commissioner of Police removed the defect, if any."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains curing of irregularity in order.

key_quotes.text: "Having regard to the class of cases to which this sub-section applies and the menace which an externment order passed under it is intended to avert, it is difficult to say that this provision is unreasonable."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on reasonableness under Article 19(5).

key_quotes.text: "This object would be wholly defeated if a right to confront or cross-examine these witnesses was given to the suspect."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies lack of cross-examination in procedure.
